Aufnahmedatum: 2011-05-15 21:40 UTC

Recorder: Zoom H4N im Fokus eines selbstgebauten Parabolspiegels montiert

Nachbearbeitung: Frequenzbereich unterhalb 500 Hz leicht abgesenkt durch Hochpaßfilterung,
keine sonstige Nachbearbeitung außer Pegelanhebung (Normalisierung), Resampling (96kHz auf 48kHz) und MP3 Encoding

Lebensraum: Obstbäume und Büsche, etwa 5m neben der Straße, 
der aufgenommene Vogel saß in einem Obstbaum ca. 2m hoch und 5m entfernt

Im Hintergrund sind ist leise eine weitere Nachtigall zu hören, die ca. 20-30m entfernt war.

Die Umgebung war extrem ruhig, bei völliger Windstille

recordings.rmk: could be hybrid among L.l and L.m

Normalized recording, otherwise unmodified. Sounds precisely like in real life. 

Habitat is a old abandoned overgrown garden outside city bounds with cherry and mirabelle trees surrounded by open fields. 
I could not see the bird clearly since it keeps pretty hidden but i believe it to be of the size of a sparrow / finch. 

The "croak" you can hear is part of the call, i first thought i had some frogs sitting in the trees but it is definitely part of the call. It usually goes "tweet - croak", but sometimes the bird just uses the tweets without the odd croaking sound.


I also believe this to be an alarm call since the bird was following me around, while still keeping hidden in the bushes and trees.

Singing from scrub. Thrush Nightingale also lives nearby which I have found in the allotments and around Kabel within a few hundred metres to the west of here (see my recording XC414627). All of the Nightingales in this meadow appeared to be Luscinia megarhynchos. No editing. Olympus LS12 and Sennheiser ME66.

I used ZOOM-H1 handy recorder for the recording. At the beginning the file was recorded as WAV and then converted to MP3. Except this the recording was not modified. The bird has a nest in the recording area near the lake Egirdir and it sings during the day and the night. The habitat is simply covered with shrubs, bushes and trees. I took some night recordings too. As I see the bird was in good condition as physically.
Recorded in a group of small trees and bushes.  Minimal editing with Audacity.

recordings.loc: observatorio de la rocina, el rocío, huelva, andalucía
recordings.rmk: En este observatorio hay una serie de senderos que transcurren por una especie de compendio de todos los ecosistemas de la zona. hay pinares, que por cierto tienen muchas ramas secas que al moverse3 con el viento emiten un lúgubre castañeteo, bosque mediterréno, praderas abiertas y también un arroyo con vegetación cruzado por un puente. Además hay varios observatorios en unas cuantas lagunas.

recordings.rmk:
Dense shrub vegetation near riverbed. 
Recording not filtered.

We saw the bird in the area about 30 minutes before this recording but not while singing. Song coming from thick vegetation along a canal between two lakes. 

It is always difficult for me to separate Turdus philomelos from Luscinia megarhynchos because some phrases are fairly similar, and here, because we saw the thrush too.

recordings.rmk: Abberant song of a presumed Common Nightingale. In 2013, I recorded the same type of song on exactly the same spot. Probably, this bird has abnormal vocal cords, since it is only producing this syllabe all the time....
Five quarters before sunrise.  It was already no full song when I arrived, and then he stopped early, after a series of calls.  [52.114682, 4.335096, ul140614]

L.l. -   0:56

Registration modified slightly with the elimination of background noise
The bird was placed on a tree
I was settled for a long recording but suddenly he remembered a Very Important Meeting, snapped a Yponomeuta caterpillar from a Hawthorn and left. [52.124062, 4.340453, ul140525]

Bird singing from a huge bush of mimosa and small pine trees. Probably the nest-site. This bird is present since several days and sings from the same bush. Impossible to see it even we can approach fairly close to the bush while it continues to sing loudly.

recordings.rmk: Typical song

Loud song coming from a huge bush of mimosa and small pine trees in cultivated area. The bird was very close to us, but it has been impossible to see it. It was probably close to its nest-site. 
However, the Common Chiffchaff was perched just above our heads while calling continuously! 
Some wind in background in the middle of the recording (not modified).

Minimum recording distance c. 4m. Volume reduced. 'Thin' acoustics caused by a big wall of logs, protecting a hedgerow against grazing. In the end the Blackbird comes very close. [bpzw52.068533,4.449843, ul140501]
